definition: to string together/to skewer/to connect wrongly/to gang up/to rove/string/bunch/skewer/classifier for things that are strung together, or in a bunch, or in a row: string of, bunch of, series of/to make a swift or abrupt linear movement (like a bead on an abacus)/to move across
classifier for an activity, taken in its entirety (tirade of abuse, stint of music playing, bout of drinking etc)
to go through/to know well/(suffix) expert/to connect/to communicate/open/to clear/classifier for letters, telegrams, phone calls etc

sentences.english: And you conspire with him against me, do you, viper?
sentences.chinese: 你和他串通一起反對我，是吧，毒蛇？

sentences.english: A plot that colludes with by politician and sinister gang is approaching rude good people.
sentences.chinese: 一個由政客和黑幫串通的陰謀正在逼近野良。

sentences.english: Several companies gang up to raise prices.
sentences.chinese: 幾家公司串通一氣擡高物價。

sentences.english: People always conspire to keep the truth from me.
sentences.chinese: 人們總是串通一氣不把真情告訴我。

sentences.english: I know who rides with Théoden of Rohan.
sentences.chinese: 我知道誰跟羅翰國的塞奧頓串通一氣。

sentences.english: Collusive price leadership characterizes oligopolistic markets .
sentences.chinese: 串通式價格領導具有寡佔市場的特徵。

sentences.english: Zhang confessed that and open collusion locksmith, made from burglary, theft 8.
sentences.chinese: 張某交待了和開鎖匠串通，製造的8起入室盜竊案。

sentences.english: My mother colluded in the myth of him as the swanky businessman .
sentences.chinese: 我母親和別人串通，把他杜撰成一個闊氣的商人。

sentences.english: He felt that his colleagues were conspiring together to remove him from his job.
sentences.chinese: 他覺得他的同事們正串通密謀把他從職位上趕下來。

sentences.english: Article 41 Malicious collusion between bidders makes the auction invalid.
sentences.chinese: 競買人之間惡意串通的，拍賣無效。

sentences.english: Thus, she was guilty of lying or colluding with the reporter.
sentences.chinese: 因此，她應該爲撒謊或與記者串通感到內疚。

sentences.english: Finally, law enforcement must crack down on collusion.
sentences.chinese: 最後，執法者必須與勾結串通決裂。

definition: to collude with/to collaborate with/to gang up with
to act in collusion (idiom); in cahoots with/villains will look after one another
lit. to sing a duet/fig. to collaborate with sb/also used satirically: to play second fiddle to
villains collude together (idiom); to work hand in glove with sb (to nefarious ends)
to scam/to set a trap/to set up a scheme to defraud people
to conspire to murder/to plot against sb's life
